TSJâ€™s last day filming for the show was late July (the 22nd). The entire time Iâ€™ve been hoping that TPTB released the information to throw fans off track (much like the â€˜Toddâ€™s execution scenes when, I believe, TSJâ€™s contract was up and TPTB kept us guessing about whether or not he would return. At time moves on, I realize that itâ€™s utterly hopeless to believe that TPTB are playing a waiting game and I realize that RHâ€™s Todd has indeed won out. While Iâ€™d preferred having both men onscreen, itâ€™s clear that RHâ€™s Todd had to win out. Bummer, but I accept it will adjust.

Bummer? Yes, bummer. Iâ€™ve been adamant that I want TSJ to be declared the â€˜real Toddâ€™ while keeping RHâ€™s Todd on as the newly discovered brother brainwashed into believing he was Todd Why? Although it took me a while to warm up to him, Iâ€™ve been a huge TSJ supporter since Toddâ€™s â€œdeath rowâ€ storyline. Itâ€™s one of the most ethereal, hauntingly beautiful, storylines OLTL writers have offered. A rapist, who later became a rape survivor, is on death row after being convicted of killing his assailant. I think TSJ added an intangible quality to the role that RHâ€™s Todd didnâ€™t have.

Rather than build on the magnificence of that storyline and send Todd on a journey of introspection, OLTL writers took the opportunity to make Todd meaner, angrier, and more vile with each act -primarily to prop other characters and storylines. TSJâ€™s Todd was sacrificed to sell Cole and the Starr as a burgeoning supercouple and the writers wasted no time in taking TSJâ€™s Todd to a new low (battering Cole, knocking a pregnant Starr down a flight of stiars, threatening to kill orphaned adolescents, bullying Starrâ€™s friends, etc).

Todd had become such a heinous character that OLTL writers wasted months creating a new â€˜high school musicalâ€™ around the â€œeternalâ€ love of Starr and Cole, with Todd being cast as evil personified. Much of Langstonâ€™s play centered around the heartlessness of a man like Todd, whoâ€™d lost the ability to recognize and bask in the glow of true love. When an entire townâ€™s collective life revolves around a high schol musical on the glory of teen love/pregnancy as a lesson about love for the ages? Your show and its characters are doomed. I think the show for far too long leveraged its credibility on the backs of its youngest performers (not their fault at all) in the hopes of bringing in newer/younger viewers â€” and as has always been true of daytime, younger viewers are as uninterested in hot mess storyline about their lives as the rest of us. It didnâ€™t stop TSJâ€™s Todd from becoming a causalty and beginning the downward spiral toward irrelevance.

Like RH before him, TSJâ€™s portrayal of the character became one of boredom and he began projecting â€˜shorthandâ€™ acting. His responses became quick quips. Facials expressions (plural) became facial expression (singular). The return of Marty Saybrooke was the death of TSJâ€™s Todd Manning. His struggle for redemption â€“ post Martyâ€™s rape (the first time) was gone. His sad realization that he would never be able to make up to Marty, or the community he offended and terrorized, for his actions was gone. His struggle to forgive himself for what heâ€™d become, was gone.

The writers, I can only guess, felt that theyâ€™d found the one sure fire way of giving all of that back to fans. RHâ€™s Todd gets a fresh start. If he becomes â€˜Real Toddâ€™, it means that the writers can take us back to the place where we loved the flawed Todd Manning because he would still be struggling with his humanity and his fighting his fear of returing to the sociopath heâ€™d once been (the sociopath TSJâ€™s Todd was sacrificed to become once again).

Watching Viki with Todd, even I began to long for old Todd. I remembered how instrumental a role Viki played in Toddâ€™s redepmtion and how much closer to human she made him. The few minutes of Viki with the RHToddâ€™s (the Todd who was allowed to experience human emotions) made me â€œhomesickâ€ and sad that the writers had wasted the gifts that TST brought to the role at the same time. There is something special in RHâ€™s Toddâ€™s relationship with Viki that TSJâ€™s Todd was never allowed to capture. I felt like an intruder watching Viki watch her baby brother (RH Todd) sleep. The moment felt so real and I could only imagine that in fictional Vikiâ€™s shoes that I, too, would long for the brother with a familiar face, a familiar sound and familiar mannerisms.

I get it, because as much as Iâ€™ve loved TSJ in the role and for as much as I hope there is a way to bring him back, afterall, I can see the emtional threads of this storyline braiding themselves together to give fans the Todd theyâ€™d hoped they would get with TSJ and were disappointed when the writers had other plans. EZâ€™s Viki and RHâ€™s Todd have the opportunity to bring viewers back to what feels like â€˜homeâ€™.

Initially, this storyline led me to imagine the Emmy worthy work Erika Slezak would deliver as the emotional heart of the Lord family, torn between two brothers who want to be loved best by her â€“ one who now had everything and one whoâ€™d pretty much lost it all. Both brothers would be fearful of being rejected in favor of the other. I thought of the stress and pain it would cause Viki to constantly be asked to choose between them, as it has caused her the same gutwrenching pain she experiences even still with her daughters. Ithought of the comic moments with the two sets of long lost Lord twins, RH-Todd and his favorite, Jess. TSJ -Todd becoming Nataliesâ€™s champion. In the end, while both Todds are familiar to Viki, both would be strangers. Now itâ€™s becoming clearer that the writers are going to make a â€˜choiceâ€™ themselves, and Iâ€™m resigned to the fact that their choice wonâ€™t be mine and TSJ wonâ€™t be back. More is the pity.

Ultimately, it must be hell to work for an ABC soap in a familiar role. From the return of the â€œReal Greenleeâ€ to the return of RHâ€™s Todd, any actor would probably be smart to consider themselves just a temporary long-term replacement in any ABC soap role.

No, not â€˜Basterdsâ€™, thatâ€™s Tarantinoâ€™s deal. The IBâ€™s Iâ€™m (lovingly) referring to are the daytime writers who have yet to give up on trying to pull one over on the fans!

One Life to Live

1. Iâ€™d appreciate it if someone would explain to me why Cole and Starr (of â€˜Weâ€™re Cole and Starrâ€™ fame) would think it was â€˜okâ€™ to involve Starr in Coleâ€™s â€˜21 Jump Streetâ€˜ drug operation. That wonâ€™t stop me from cringing whenever Starr and Cole are on. The longer this pairing goes on, the weaker the writing for them becomes. 2. I donâ€™t care who Rexâ€™s father isâ€¦ itâ€™s dragged on too long without enough plot points in between to keep me curious. Now Iâ€™m just annoyed every time the topic comes up. 3. Fish and Kyle. Daytime writers seem to believe that all gays have a traumatic coming out experience. I would have much rather had Fish avoid Kyle because he gave his heart and soul to Kyle in college and Kyle cheated, lied, and was generally unconcerned about anyone but himself. At some point, writers, can we please just have gay characters who are actually HAPPY with their lives, and not afraid that their friends and family will turn on them? Am I watching too much Miami Social? (Yeah, I should be ashamed of admitting that too! That cast of real life characters puts the â€˜superâ€™ in superficial!)

So how have the writers topped themselves? HA! Itâ€™s the fruit of Sonnyâ€™s loins (product of the pecker) who is now being sent to take him down! Marked improvement, writers, reallyâ€¦ only not! 2. Nikâ€¦ calling Emily Rebecca a â€˜whoreâ€™ and â€˜slutâ€™ and repeatedly making reference to how easily she â€˜spreads her legsâ€™â€¦ just lovelyâ€¦ As much as I despise Rebecca, I would have cheered her on for slapping â€˜Prince Nikolasâ€™ out of his shoes, thank you very much! The Bold and The Beautiful

Speaking of showers, did anyone watch KKLâ€™s Brooke and HTâ€™s Taylor mud wrestling scene? Obviously, I didnâ€™t, but as I understand it, the actresses (their characters) took a â€˜mud bathâ€™ to cleanse their toxins and a fight broke out between the characters.

Tsk, tsk, tsk, The Bold and The Beautiful writers.

Letâ€™s rid ourselves of all of the bad editors! (if you donâ€™t mind the turn of phrase).Most of what took place on OLTL this past week pleasantly surprised me. Even my well worn remote would like to take this moment to thank the writers for relief. It pretty much had the week off with One Life, since I donâ€™t remember hitting FF once this week. The only big shocker for me this past week were several pretty lousy editing choices, one in particular. Iâ€™ll get to that in a moment.

Soap-heaven help me, I still like John and Marty. The only thing thatâ€™s harder to take than a dark and brooding John McBain is John McBain in love. â€˜Happyâ€™ John and â€˜Broodingâ€™ John are pretty much one in the same. Itâ€™s just at times tough to watch a man who SHOULD be filled with joy behave like a man whose problems could all be solved with the help of a good laxative. Wardrobe, could you PLEASE at least put on a brightly colored shirt under his dark suit jacket and dark coat, to go along with his dark pants and dark shoes so that we know the difference between Brooding John and Joyous John? Thanks!

Johnâ€™s reaction to Marty as she flashed back on her the manipulated-rape sex with Todd was a reminder that there are soap writers who still realize that itâ€™s so much easier for fans to root for good men â€“ we get so few of them in daytime. Many of us still love men who are sensitive to the needs of others, rather than focus on themselves and their own pain. LOVED that moment when John reminded Marty that he was always willing to wait for her â€“ sheâ€™s worth it. LOVED that the writers didnâ€™t follow that scene up with John immediately running to someone else to flirt with or have sex with while Marty was working on her recovery.

The only thing that made the scene even remotely awkward was watching Blair seduce Todd at the same time Marty had difficulty being touched by John because of Toddâ€™s assault of her. If the writers wanted to make some of us squeamish about Todd and Blair, job well done. Otherwise? Bad editing job on this one. It made Todd and Blair seem completely disconnected from the world around them, belligerently insular. They seemed to not care about how much damage had been done to others in their time apart.

Blair, who was disgusted by Toddâ€™s treatment of Marty, seems to have absolutely no qualms about his actions, now. She was disgusted enough before to want to keep his children from him. Now? She canâ€™t keep her hands off of him.

I would much rather have had long soulful talks between the two rather than strip scenes and â€œshame-filledâ€ sex. The problem with the writing for the once magnificent Todd and Blair is that that the writers donâ€™t seem invested in having them break the inch deep-mile wide pattern theyâ€™ve established as part of their courtship. OLTL writers have seem to always bank on the hard work of Kassie DePaiva and Trevor St. John in winning back fans to the â€˜Todd and Blair corner to bring romance back to the show. I think theyâ€™ll have to reconsider, this time. Too much damage has been done and an instant reunion most likely wonâ€™t give them the bump theyâ€™re looking for. How instant is instant in their case? Todd/Blair reunions can be summarized by the following dialogue:

â€œYou hurt meâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter).

â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

â€œStay away from meâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

â€œYou donâ€™t mean thatâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

They have sexâ€¦ AND SCENE!

Where is the discussion about what they want and why they want it? What about some insight into why they dragged Marty and John into their psychodrama? How about some part humorous/part dramatic couples counseling for them? What about real consideration about Teaâ€™s feelings? Itâ€™s bad enough that Todd cheated on Tea after she put everything on the line for him, her life included, but he then lied and said that it meant nothing that heâ€™d had sex with Blair. If it wasnâ€™t a lie that having sex with Blair meant nothing to him? It makes his actions even worse. The writers rubbed salt in fansâ€™ wounds by having Todd coldly state to Blair that he was leaving her to go after Tea â€˜because sheâ€™s worth itâ€™.

Hells bells, people, you know that despite Teaâ€™s fault, Iâ€™m a fan of the goddess of grand bitchery but for TODD to state who is â€˜worthyâ€™ and who isnâ€™t? Well that just burns my grits. I would have loved watching Blair get up off the chaise lounge and slap Todd back to his infancy (which would finally allow his external state match his internal state)! Marty, Tea, Blair, his sister Viki, and even his own daughter, Starrâ€¦ just how many women in Llanview are going to end up emotionally scarred thanks to this guy? Taking Todd down the dark road for the sake of pimping â€œStarr and Coleâ€ is a decision that still haunts this show. The writers havenâ€™t been able to find their â€˜Todd mojoâ€™ and get anything right with this character since then.

Despite the detour and bad editing, I enjoy Marty and John.

What else was there to love?

1. Greg turned out to not be a big a jerk as he originally seemed. I liked that he experienced pangs of guilt about running out on Destiny and realizing that heâ€™d hurt her with his actions. While Starr moved one step closer to being a â€˜real momâ€™, Gigi took a step back for me. (Wait, Iâ€™m getting to itâ€¦ thereâ€™s something I like about this storyline, hang on)â€¦ It was odd to watch her encourage Shaneâ€™s hatred of Aunt Stacy no matter how much of a low life Stacy has been.

SO, hereâ€™s what I loved

A â€“ That the â€˜secretâ€™ is finally out in the open. I was tired of this storyline about a month before it began (damn you spoilers!)
